<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>

<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> pendennis's most kind offer <\s>

<s> she had seen that look more than once of late pursuing her <\s>

<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>
<s> pen spouted byron and moore passion and poetry her business was to throw up her eyes or fixing them for a moment on his face to cry oh tis beautiful <\s>
<s> repeat those lines again <\s>

<s> how delightful those interviews were <\s>
<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>
<s> how he worked and screamed and twisted and repeated lines over and over again and with what indomitable patience and dulness she followed him <\s>
<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>

<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>

<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>
<s> pen spouted byron and moore passion and poetry her business was to throw up her eyes or fixing them for a moment on his face to cry oh tis beautiful <\s>
<s> repeat those lines again <\s>
<s> and off the boy went and she returned to her own simple thoughts about the turned gown or the hashed mutton <\s>
<s> in fact pen's passion was not long a secret from the lovely emily or her father <\s>

<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>

<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>

<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>
<s> how he worked and screamed and twisted and repeated lines over and over again and with what indomitable patience and dulness she followed him <\s>
<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> when informed under the most solemn vows of secrecy of pen's condition of mind the curate said with no small tremor that he hoped it was no unworthy object no unlawful attachment which pen had formed for if so the poor fellow felt it would be his duty to break his vow and inform pen's mother and then there would be a quarrel he felt with sickening apprehension and he would never again have a chance of seeing what he most liked in the world <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> pendennis did not much read the works in question yet he enjoined pen to peruse them and often said what pleasure he should have when the boy was of a proper age in taking him and mother to see some good plays of the immortal poet <\s>

<s> pendennis's most kind offer <\s>
<s> as he spoke he gave her a look which made her exceedingly uncomfortable <\s>
<s> she had seen that look more than once of late pursuing her <\s>
<s> he became more positively odious every day in the widow's eyes <\s>
<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>
<s> pen spouted byron and moore passion and poetry her business was to throw up her eyes or fixing them for a moment on his face to cry oh tis beautiful <\s>
<s> repeat those lines again <\s>
<s> and off the boy went and she returned to her own simple thoughts about the turned gown or the hashed mutton <\s>
<s> in fact pen's passion was not long a secret from the lovely emily or her father <\s>
<s> upon his second visit his admiration was quite evident to both of them and on his departure the old gentleman said to his daughter as he winked at her over his glass of grog faith milly darling i think ye've hooked that chap <\s>
<s> pooh tis only a boy papa dear milly remarked <\s>
<s> sure he's but a child <\s>
<s> pen would have been very much pleased if he had heard that phrase he was galloping home wild with pleasure and shouting out her name as he rode <\s>
<s> ye've hooked um any how said the captain and let me tell ye he's not a bad fish <\s>

<s> them boys are mostly talk said milly seriously <\s>
<s> ye know at dublin how ye went on about young poldoody and i've a whole desk full of verses he wrote me when he was in trinity college but he went abroad and his mother married him to an englishwoman <\s>

<s> ye needn't be afraid about the young chap i think i'm old enough to take care of myself captain costigan <\s>
<s> so pen used to come day after day rushing in and galloping away and growing more wild about the girl with every visit <\s>
<s> sometimes the captain was present at their meetings but having a perfect confidence in his daughter he was more often inclined to leave the young couple to themselves and cocked his hat over his eye and strutted off on some errand when pen entered <\s>
<s> how delightful those interviews were <\s>
<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>
<s> how he worked and screamed and twisted and repeated lines over and over again and with what indomitable patience and dulness she followed him <\s>
<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>
<s> the post horses from the clavering arms arrived in due time and carried the party to the theatre at chatteris where pen was gratified in perceiving that a tolerably large audience was assembled <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>

<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> pendennis's most kind offer <\s>

<s> he became more positively odious every day in the widow's eyes <\s>
<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>
<s> pen spouted byron and moore passion and poetry her business was to throw up her eyes or fixing them for a moment on his face to cry oh tis beautiful <\s>
<s> repeat those lines again <\s>
<s> and off the boy went and she returned to her own simple thoughts about the turned gown or the hashed mutton <\s>
<s> in fact pen's passion was not long a secret from the lovely emily or her father <\s>

<s> sure he's but a child <\s>

<s> so pen used to come day after day rushing in and galloping away and growing more wild about the girl with every visit <\s>
<s> sometimes the captain was present at their meetings but having a perfect confidence in his daughter he was more often inclined to leave the young couple to themselves and cocked his hat over his eye and strutted off on some errand when pen entered <\s>
<s> how delightful those interviews were <\s>
<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>
<s> how he worked and screamed and twisted and repeated lines over and over again and with what indomitable patience and dulness she followed him <\s>
<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>

<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> when informed under the most solemn vows of secrecy of pen's condition of mind the curate said with no small tremor that he hoped it was no unworthy object no unlawful attachment which pen had formed for if so the poor fellow felt it would be his duty to break his vow and inform pen's mother and then there would be a quarrel he felt with sickening apprehension and he would never again have a chance of seeing what he most liked in the world <\s>

<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>

<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>

<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> so pen used to come day after day rushing in and galloping away and growing more wild about the girl with every visit <\s>
<s> sometimes the captain was present at their meetings but having a perfect confidence in his daughter he was more often inclined to leave the young couple to themselves and cocked his hat over his eye and strutted off on some errand when pen entered <\s>
<s> how delightful those interviews were <\s>
<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>

<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>

<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>

<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> when informed under the most solemn vows of secrecy of pen's condition of mind the curate said with no small tremor that he hoped it was no unworthy object no unlawful attachment which pen had formed for if so the poor fellow felt it would be his duty to break his vow and inform pen's mother and then there would be a quarrel he felt with sickening apprehension and he would never again have a chance of seeing what he most liked in the world <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>

<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>

<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> when informed under the most solemn vows of secrecy of pen's condition of mind the curate said with no small tremor that he hoped it was no unworthy object no unlawful attachment which pen had formed for if so the poor fellow felt it would be his duty to break his vow and inform pen's mother and then there would be a quarrel he felt with sickening apprehension and he would never again have a chance of seeing what he most liked in the world <\s>
<s> pen bounced out at the curate's question <\s>
<s> she is as pure as she is beautiful i would give my heart to no other woman <\s>
<s> i keep the matter a secret in my family because because there are reasons of a weighty nature which i am not at liberty to disclose <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>

<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> pendennis's most kind offer <\s>

<s> she had seen that look more than once of late pursuing her <\s>

<s> we are not going to say a great deal about pen's courtship of miss fotheringay for the reader has already had a specimen of her conversation much of which need surely not be reported <\s>
<s> pen sate with her hour after hour and poured forth all his honest boyish soul to her <\s>
<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>
<s> one after another as his thoughts rose in his hot eager brain he clothed them in words and told them to her <\s>
<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>
<s> pen spouted byron and moore passion and poetry her business was to throw up her eyes or fixing them for a moment on his face to cry oh tis beautiful <\s>
<s> repeat those lines again <\s>

<s> how delightful those interviews were <\s>
<s> the captain's drawing room was a low wainscoted room with a large window looking into the dean's garden <\s>
<s> there pen sate and talked and talked emily looking beautiful as she sate at her work looking beautiful and calm and the sunshine came streaming in at the great windows and lighted up her superb face and form <\s>
<s> in the midst of the conversation the great bell would begin to boom and he would pause smiling and be silent until the sound of the vast music died away or the rooks in the cathedral elms would make a great noise towards sunset or the sound of the organ and the choristers would come over the quiet air and gently hush pen's talking <\s>
<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>
<s> the misfortune was that the london managers had seen her <\s>
<s> she had played in london three years before and failed from utter stupidity <\s>
<s> since then it was that bows had taken her in hand and taught her part after part <\s>
<s> how he worked and screamed and twisted and repeated lines over and over again and with what indomitable patience and dulness she followed him <\s>
<s> she knew that he made her and let herself be made <\s>
<s> she was not grateful or ungrateful or unkind or ill humoured <\s>
<s> she was only stupid and pen was madly in love with her <\s>

<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>

<s> everything he knew or hoped or felt or had read or fancied he told to her <\s>
<s> he never tired of talking and longing <\s>

<s> her part of the tete a tete was not to talk but to appear as if she understood what pen talked a difficult matter for the young fellow blurted out no small quantity of nonsense and to look exceedingly handsome and sympathising <\s>
<s> the fact is whilst he was making one of his tirades and delighted perhaps and wondering at his own eloquence the lad would go on for twenty minutes at a time the lovely emily who could not comprehend a tenth part of his talk had leisure to think about her own affairs and would arrange in her own mind how they should dress the cold mutton or how she would turn the black satin or make herself out of her scarf a bonnet like miss thackthwaite's new one and so forth <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>

<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>

<s> by the way it must be said that miss fotheringay in a plain shawl and a close bonnet and veil went to church every sunday of her life accompanied by her indefatigable father who gave the responses in a very rich and fine brogue joined in the psalms and chanting and behaved in the most exemplary manner <\s>
<s> little bows the house friend of the family was exceedingly wroth at the notion of miss fotheringay's marriage with a stripling seven or eight years her junior <\s>
<s> bows who was a cripple and owned that he was a little more deformed even than bingley the manager so that he could not appear on the stage was a singular wild man of no small talents and humour <\s>
<s> attracted first by miss fotheringay's beauty he began to teach her how to act <\s>
<s> he shrieked out in his cracked voice the parts and his pupil learned them from his lips by rote and repeated them in her full rich tones <\s>
<s> he indicated the attitudes and set and moved those beautiful arms of hers <\s>
<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
<s> bows then was indignant at the notion that his pupil should throw her chances away in life by bestowing her hand upon a little country squire <\s>
<s> as soon as a london manager saw her he prophesied that she would get a london engagement and a great success <\s>

<s> those who remember this grand actress on the stage can recall how she used always precisely the same gestures looks and tones how she stood on the same plank of the stage in the same position rolled her eyes at the same instant and to the same degree and wept with precisely the same heart rending pathos and over the same pathetic syllable <\s>
<s> and after she had come out trembling with emotion before the audience and looking so exhausted and tearful that you fancied she would faint with sensibility she would gather up her hair the instant she was behind the curtain and go home to a mutton chop and a glass of brown stout and the harrowing labours of the day over she went to bed and snored as resolutely and as regularly as a porter <\s>
